Award.AbstractNarration: The project is part of the general field of 3-dimensional topology and geometry, which analyzes 3-dimensional spaces with a high level of complexity and includes the study of the knotting phenomena that occur for curves in three dimensions. The underlying problems often arise from practical applications in the three-dimensional world we live in, but also from more theoretical considerations in mathematical physics. The project investigates a surprising connection between two very different approaches to 3-dimensional topology. The first approach is very algebraic and involves so-called quantum invariants for knotted curves in 3-dimensional spaces. The second approach is more geometric and analytic, and uses the non-euclidean geometry of the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space. The Kashaev Volume Conjecture, experimentally verified on many examples but still without a mathematical proof guaranteeing that it holds in all cases, provides an unexpected connection between these two viewpoints. The award provides support for graduate students who will be involved in related research.<br/><br/>More precisely, the Kashaev Volume Conjecture connects the asymptotics of the colored Jones polynomial of a knot to the hyperbolic volume of its complement. This tantalizing conjecture is now 25-year old, and supported by much heuristic and experimental evidence. However, the corresponding property has been rigorously proved for only a very small number of cases. The goal of the project is to develop various steps in a roadmap towards a proof of the Kashaev Volume Conjecture, with a special emphasis on its analytic subtleties. As a first step, the project is focused on a closely related conjecture for surface bundles over the circle, where the combinatorics of quantum invariants are more clearly connected to the geometry of the underlying manifold. The PI and his collaborators will attack this conjecture in the even more special case of punctured torus bundles, in an effort to be very concrete while tackling the analytic difficulties that arise in this context. The PI will then build on the experience, insights and technical expertise gathered in this first case to proceed with the next steps in the roadmap, one after the other.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project addressed an important problem in the field of 3-dimensional topology and geometry. This general area of mathematics is devoted to the study of 3-dimensional spaces with a high level of complexity, and for instance includes knotting phenomena for 1-dimensional objects (such as abstract curves, but also complex molecules and DNA strands for some practical applications) in three dimensions. The question motivating the project is the Kashaev Volume Conjecture which proposes a surprising connection between two extremely different approaches to these types of problems, respectively arising from the subfields of quantum topology and (non-euclidean) hyperbolic geometry.

The PI and his collaborators addressed a closely related conjecture connecting, for a purely 2-dimensional object, the output of certain quantum topological constructions to the hyperbolic volume of an associated 3-dimensional space. They untangled the subtleties of this new conjecture, and proved it in several special cases. The motivation for the consideration of this slightly easier problem was to develop novel technical tools that could be used to attack the original Kashaev Volume Conjecture, and the project has been quite successful in this regard.

This line of investigation was greatly developed during the period of the award, and is still being expanded. The PI and his collaborators disseminated two prepublications devoted to different aspects of the program, and are putting the finishing touches on a third one containing what possibly are the most novel outcomes of their research. Once this series is completed and harmonized, these three articles will be submitted for publication in peer-reviewed journals.

In addition to its scientific output, the award contributed to the training of a graduate student whose doctoral work was centered on the volumes of truncated hyperbolic tetrahedra, a fundamental block in the hyperbolic geometry approach to 3-dimensional topology.
